chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of fibroids
chapter.summary: Covers the management of women with fibroids.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards (Female).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage fibroids?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If imaging shows the presence of uterine fibroids, appropriate treatment should be planned with the woman, based on the size, number, and location of the fibroids and her symptoms. 
    • Refer to a specialist, women with: 
      • Complications, such as compressive symptoms from large fibroids (for example dyspareunia, pelvic pain or discomfort, constipation, or urinary symptoms).
      • Fertility or obstetric problems associated with fibroids — for more information, see the CKS topic on Infertility.
      • A clinical or radiological suspicion of malignancy.
      • Fibroids which are palpable abdominally, or intracavity fibroids and/or whose uterine length is measured at ultrasound, or hysteroscopy, greater than 12 cm.
    • For women with fibroids that are asymptomatic:
      • The majority of women require no further investigation or treatment once diagnosed unless there is rapid growth or reason to suspect pelvic malignancy.
      • Arrange annual follow up to monitor size and growth.
    • For women with menorrhagia associated with fibroids, see the CKS topic on Menorrhagia for management information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the British Medical Journal (BMJ) best practice guide Uterine fibroids [BMJ, 2017], the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) guideline Heavy menstrual bleeding: assessment and management [NICE, 2018], and expert opinion in a narrative review Fibroids: diagnosis and management [Lumsden, 2015].

Specialist referral
  • Expert opinion in a narrative review recommends that women with symptomatic fibroids which do not respond to initial treatments require referral to secondary care [Lumsden, 2015].
  • CKS consider that in these circumstances, referral to a specialist is warranted to consider other medical and/or surgical treatment options.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What methods of contraception are recommended for women with fibroids?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• For women with uterine fibroids:
    • Without distortion of the uterine cavity — all methods can be used.
      • However, depending on the location and size of the fibroid, sterilization may be difficult.
    • With distortion of the uterine cavity — advise the woman to use one of the following methods:
      • Barrier methods (condoms, diaphragms, and caps).
      • Combined hormonal contraception (pill, transdermal patch, or combined vaginal ring).
      • Progestogen-only pill (POP), progestogen-only implant, or progestogen-only injectable.
      • Female sterilization — depending on the location and size of the fibroid, sterilization may be difficult.
    • Consider the following methods only after seeking specialist advice as the risks usually outweigh the benefits:
      • Copper intrauterine device (Cu-IUD) or levonorgestrel intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) — these may be difficult to fit. 
  • For more information, see the section on fibroids in CKS topic on Contraception - assessment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) UK medical eligibility criteria for contraceptive [FSRH, 2016] and the World Health Organization (WHO) guidance Medical eligibility for contraceptive use [WHO, 2015].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Can I prescribe HRT for women with fibroids?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• For women with no symptoms from their fibroids:
    • The decision to treat menopausal symptoms with hormone replacement therapy (HRT) should be taken by the woman after she has been informed of the possible risks and benefits of treatment (as for all women considering HRT). This should include an explanation that:
      • In some women, HRT may modestly increase fibroid size. If this occurs, there is a small risk that it will cause symptoms.
    • After starting HRT in women with fibroids:
      • Enquire about symptoms from fibroids at each review, and advise the woman to return for an early review if symptoms develop at any time. For more information, see the section on Managing menopausal symptoms with HRT in the CKS topic on Menopause.
  • For women with symptoms attributable to fibroids, seek specialist advice before prescribing HRT.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on expert opinion in narrative reviews Fibroids: diagnosis and management [Lumsden, 2015], and Etiology, symptomatology, and diagnosis of uterine myomas [Parker, 2007], and what CKS considers good clinical practice. 

  • Hormonal replacement therapy (HRT) may cause some growth of fibroids, but this is of uncertain clinical importance [Lumsden, 2015].
  • The risk of symptoms due to fibroid enlargement caused by HRT is considered by experts to be low [Parker, 2007].
